Graphical abstract The HZSM-5 catalyst modified with Ga species exhibits excellent reaction performance for propane dehydroaromatization, a process that involves propane dehydrogenation to propylene, and further formation of aromatics via polymerization, cyclization, dehydrogenation, etc. The detailed mechanism of the synergistic effect between Ga species and Brønsted acid with each other during propane dehydroaromatization remains unclear due to the complexity and extreme branching of aromatization reaction pathways. In this study, the complete reaction process for propane dehydroaromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5 is investigated based on the density functional theory (DFT) method. The results indicate that the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts with [GaH]2+ species at all studied sites show superior thermodynamic and kinetic stability, with only [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites exhibiting excellent dehydrogenation performance. In propane dehydroaromatization, the dehydrogenation reactions dominated by [GaH]2+ species tend to occur on the framework O atom surrounding [GaH]2+ species with stronger Lewis base strength, while polymerization and cyclization reactions dominated by Brønsted acid tend to occur on Brønsted acid with stronger acid strength. The synergistic effect between [GaH]2+ species and Brønsted acid is reflected in the fact that the [GaH]2+ species can indirectly improve the activity of propylene polymerization and C6 diene cyclization reactions on the Brønsted acid by enhancing the Brønsted acid strength, and in turn, the Brønsted acid enables the [GaH]2+ species to exist more stably kinetically by promoting the conversion of [GaH2]+ species to [GaH]2+ species. This study contributes to the enriched understanding of the Brønsted/Lewis acid synergistic effect and the role of acidity-basicity during propane dehydroaromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5. Keywords Propane dehydroaromatization DFT Ga-modified HZSM-5 Synergistic effect Acidity-basicity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propane is an important component of shale gas [1]. In recent years, with the more accessible exploration and utilization of shale gas resources by hydraulic fracturing technology, the efficient utilization of propane has become a vital issue [2]. Benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX), as important raw materials in chemical production, depend severely on the traditional petroleum route, which hardly meets the market demand due to high preparation cost and demand [3]. Therefore, the conversion of propane, a difficult-to-utilize and abundant gas, into high-value-added BTX products is an attractive alternative process that has attracted widespread interest [4,5]. Currently, commercially available processes for the dehydroaromatization of light alkanes, including Cyclar [6] and Aroforming [7], rely primarily on zeolite catalysts. Among various zeolite materials, HZSM-5 zeolite is an excellent candidate for light alkanes dehydroaromatization reaction due to its tunable acidity and pore size that matches with aromatic molecules [8]. Since unmodified HZSM-5 zeolite exhibits low aromatic selectivity [9], modification by introducing metal species can significantly improve the activity and aromatic selectivity of the light alkanes dehydroaromatization reaction. Of the metals species considered, Ga species modified HZSM-5 zeolite is highly selective and stable, which is particularly effective for catalyzing the dehydroaromatization reaction of light alkanes [10–14]. Among the previously reported Ga species, including [GaH2]+, Ga+, [GaO]+, [GaH]2+, [Ga2O2]2+, etc [15–19], the [GaH]2+ species exhibit excellent alkane dehydrogenation activity, which would be favorable for dehydroaromatization reaction of light alkanes. Although the modification by metal species has been documented to facilitate the aromatization reaction over HZSM-5 zeolite, previous studies on olefin aromatization reactions indicate that metal species are effective in promoting the aromatization reaction process only in the presence of Brønsted acid sites. A significant loss of catalytic activity occurs when these Brønsted acid sites are removed by K+ ion exchange or pyridine titration [20,21]. Bell and co-workers [22] concluded that the rate of ethene oligomerization can be significantly improved in the presence of Ga species, which results in more butene products. All of these studies suggest that a synergistic effect between metal species and Brønsted acid can greatly facilitate the dehydroaromatization process. Concerning the nature of the synergistic effect, Deng and co-workers [23] have discovered that the synergistic effect between Ga species and Brønsted acid improves light aromatics yield by enhancing the acidity of Brønsted acid. The same synergistic effect was also observed in the dissociation process of methane on Zn/HZSM-5 [24]. In addition, Rimer and co-workers [25] and Lercher and co-workers [26] have proposed that between metal species and Brønsted acid, the synergistic effect existed derives from the redistribution of these two active centers, thereby greatly improving the activity of the dehydrogenation or polymerization reaction. Although the synergistic effect between Ga species and Brønsted acid in the aromatization reaction over modified HZSM-5 catalysts has been investigated to some extent, due to the complexity and extreme branching of complete aromatization pathways [25], the research on the detailed mechanism of the synergistic effect between Ga species and Brønsted acid with each other remains unclear, particularly the role of Brønsted acid on Ga species. In addition, it has been extensively studied that the Brønsted acid site in HZSM-5, a representative of acidic catalysts, strongly influences the activity of various reactions, such as methanol to olefin [27], alkane and olefin cleavage [28,29], methylation and hydroisomerization reactions [30,31], etc. However, the basicity of HZSM-5 zeolite is relatively less studied compared to the acidity in HZSM-5 zeolite. Hensen and co-workers [32] have revealed that the extraframework oxygen anions within small oxidic clusters improve the activation of propane due to their stronger basicity compared to the oxygen anions within the zeolite framework. Huang and co-workers [33] and Deng and co-workers [34] have concluded that the basic Si-O-Al site, as a proton acceptor, is essential for promoting the conversion of ethanol and methanol. As with the acid site, the basic Si-O-Al site in HZSM-5 zeolites has an important effect on the activity of the catalytic reaction, however, the role of the basic Si-O-Al site in HZSM-5 zeolites during propane dehydroaromatization remains unclear. In this study, the complete reaction process of propane dehydroaromatization on [GaH]2+/HZSM-5 is investigated based on the DFT method, including propane dehydrogenation to propylene, and further formation of aromatics via polymerization, cyclization, dehydrogenation, etc. The thermodynamic and kinetic stability of the [GaH]2+ species is explored by the conversion of [GaH]2+ species to [GaH2]+ and Ga+ species. The dehydrogenation reaction activity of the Ga-modified HZSM-5 is analyzed with [GaH]2+ species at different sites. The effect of the Lewis base strength of the framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species on H2 disproportionation, H transfer, and dehydrogenation reactions and the effect of the Brønsted acid strength on polymerization and cyclization reactions are investigated. Finally, the detailed mechanism of the synergistic effect between [GaH]2+ species and Brønsted acid with each other is revealed, including their contribution to the overall propane dehydroaromatization. The results provide new insights into the Brønsted/Lewis acid synergistic effect and the role of acidity-basicity during propane dehydroaromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5. 2 Computational methods and model The ONIOM theoretical model (B3LYP/6-31G (d, p): PM6) [35–38] was used for all geometry optimization and transition state (TS) via the Gaussian 16 package [39,40]. The GD3BJ parameters were used to more accurately describe the dispersion interactions in the Ga-modified HZSM-5 [41]. The only one imaginary frequency for all transition states (TS) is ensured by the OPT = TS method [42]. To verify that all transition states (TS) in the calculation were connected to the corresponding reactants and products, the quasi-internal reaction coordinate (IRC) method was applied for confirmation [43,44]. Calculation of the energetic span in free energy profiles was based on the energetic span model proposed by Kozuch and Shaik [45,46]. All relevant energy values were corrected by zero point energy (ZPE). The calculation formulas of the related parameters were available in the Supplementary Material. The HZSM-5 zeolite was obtained from the database of the International Zeolite Association for this study [47]. The 96 T cluster model structure of the HZSM-5 zeolite covered straight and zigzag channels as well as their intersection cavity, which acted as the main region of the propane dehydroaromatization reaction, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). The terminal Si-H bond was fixed at 1.470 Å, whereas the rest of the structure remained relaxed. In Ga-modified HZSM-5 bifunctional catalysts with [GaH]2+ species and Brønsted acid, the Brønsted acid was considered at the T12 site located in the intersection cavity [48,49]. Considering that Lewis acid was a divalent [GaH]2+ cation, a pair of Al atoms in the HZSM-5 framework was required to charge compensation. The Al atom was separated from the T12 site by one Si atom (AlT12-O-Si-O-Al) or two Si atoms (AlT12-O-Si-O-Si-O-Al) following the Löwenstein rule. Therefore, the active region of the high layer under the above conditions was designed to be 21T, while the other atoms were selected as the low layer, as shown in Fig. 1(b). Only a small difference was found in the calculated energy barriers and reaction energies of C–H bond activation for 21T, 24T, 27T, 30T, and 33T clusters during propane dehydrogenation on Ga-modified HZSM-5, as seen in Table S1. The maximum differences in calculated energy barriers and reaction energies were 13.1 and 10.5 kJ/mol, respectively. It suggested that our ONIOM model approach was not influenced significantly by the cluster size of the high layer active region used. As shown in Fig. 2 , the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts with [GaH]2+ species at the eight sites were constructed in the 21T active region. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Conversion and stability of [GaH]2+ species 3.1.1 Conversion of [GaH]2+ species In the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts, the [GaH]2+ species may be converted to other species during the propane dehydroaromatization reaction, which influences the performance of the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts. Bell and co-workers [15] suggested that the [GaH]2+ species may be converted to the [GaH2]+ species via the H2 disproportionation reaction ([GaH]2++H2 → H++[GaH2]+) or to the Ga+ species via the H transfer reaction ([GaH]2+→H++Ga+), as illustrated in Scheme 1 . They concluded that the [GaH]2+ species have a higher dehydrogenation activity than the [GaH2]+ and Ga+ species. Therefore, the conversions of [GaH]2+ species will directly influence the activity and stability of the active center in the propane dehydroaromatization reaction on Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts. Since the [GaH]2+ species at different sites have different framework O environments, the H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions occur on Ga-modified HZSM-5, which exists the possibility to occur on different framework O atoms surrounding the [GaH]2+ species, as shown in Fig. 3 . For example with the [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 site in Fig. 3, H2 is initially adsorbed near the [GaH]2+ species in the H2 disproportionation reaction. And then one of the H atoms in H2 is attracted to the Ga atom by the H-H bond cleavage, while the other H atom may be attracted to the six framework O atoms (O-1 to O-6) surrounding [GaH]2+ species. Similarly, in the H transfer reaction, the H atom of the [GaH]2+ species may also transfer to the six framework O atoms (O-1 to O-6) surrounding [GaH]2+ species by the Ga-H bond cleavage. To this end, the framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species at all sites are named, as illustrated in Fig. 3. It is noteworthy that the surrounding framework O atoms at a great distance from the H atom of the [GaH]2+ species are excluded since [GaH]2+ species are unlikely to be converted on these framework O atoms. The E a of H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions on [GaH]2+ species at all sites are illustrated in Fig. 4 , and the specific values of E a and ΔE are given in Table S2. It is found that for all [GaH]2+ sites, the H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions on different framework O atoms are endothermic, suggesting that the [GaH]2+ species at all studied sites are stable thermodynamically. In addition, The E a of the H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions on different framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species exhibits significant distinctions. For example with the [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 site, the E a of the H transfer reaction on the O-1 atom is as high as 262.5 kJ/mol, but only 129.0 kJ/mol on the O-5 atom. The similar situation is observed in H2 disproportionation reaction. It suggests that H transfer reaction would be unlikely to occur on the O-1 atom, and H2 disproportionation reaction would be unlikely to occur on the O-4 atom. The environment of framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species has a significant effect on the activity of H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions. The position of the framework O atoms at which the H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions are most likely to occur is identified, as shown circled in Fig. 3. The H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions on Ga-modified HZSM-5 with [GaH]2+ species will preferentially occur on the O atoms circled in Fig. 3. Considering that the different framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species exhibit different reaction activity, the Lewis base strength and Mulliken charge of the framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species are analyzed. The base strength is evaluated by the proton affinity energy (E PA) parameter, which is defined as the energy released when an acidic proton adsorbs at the Si-O-Al site of HZSM-5 to form a conjugate acid [50,51], and the calculation formulas are available in the Supplementary Material. The greater the value of the proton affinity energy (E PA), the stronger the base strength of the framework O atoms of HZSM-5. The relationship between energy barriers of H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions on the different framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species at all sites and the base strength and the Mulliken charge of the framework O atoms is shown in Fig. 5 . The specific values of the energy barrier, base strength, and Mulliken charge are listed in Tables S2-S3. The framework O atom with the optimal H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions activity exhibits stronger Lewis base strength and more negative Mulliken charges than the other framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species, as shown circled in Fig. 5. It may be attributed to the stronger attraction of this framework O atom to acidic and positively charged H protons generated by Ga-H bond cleavage and H-H bond cleavage in H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions. It is noteworthy that the framework O atom with a Mulliken charge of −0.575 e exhibits the optimal H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions activity on Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalyst with [GaH]2+ species at the T11-T6 site. Consequently, the Lewis base strength and Mulliken charge state of the framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species have an important effect on the H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions activity. 3.1.2 Stability of [GaH]2+ species It can be seen that for the same framework O atom surrounding [GaH]2+ species at all studied sites, the H2 disproportionation reaction is more easily to occur than the H transfer reaction, as shown in Fig. 4. It is consistent with the conclusions of Bell and co-workers [15]. The H2 disproportionation reaction is the primary factor influencing the stability of the [GaH]2+ species. As noted in Section 3.1.1, the H2 disproportionation reactions on the [GaH]2+ species at all studied sites are endothermic, and the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts with [GaH]2+ species exhibit superior thermodynamic stability. The kinetic stability of the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts is further analyzed by the rate constant of the forward and reverse reactions in the H2 disproportionation reaction. The conversion of [GaH]2+ to [GaH2]+ species by H2 disproportionation ([GaH]2++H2 → H++[GaH2]+) is treated as a forward reaction. And the conversion of the [GaH2]+ to [GaH]2+ species by H2 removal (H++[GaH2]+→[GaH]2++H2) is treated as a reverse reaction. The effect of temperature on the rate constant of the forward and reverse reactions of H2 disproportionation on Ga-modified HZSM-5 with [GaH]2+ species at all studied sites at the temperature range of 773–973 K is demonstrated in Fig. 6 , where the reactions all occur on the framework O atom with the optimal H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions activity. The specific values of the rate constant can be found in Table S4. It is found that the rate constant of the reverse reaction on Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts is much greater than that of the forward reaction in the temperature range considered, suggesting that [GaH2]+ is more easily converted to [GaH]2+ species compared to [GaH]2+ to [GaH2]+ species. The results show that the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts with [GaH]2+ species at all studied sites exhibit superior kinetic stability. In conclusion, the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts with [GaH]2+ species at all studied sites exhibit superior thermodynamic and kinetic stability. 3.2 Reaction pathways for propane dehydroaromatization Propane dehydroaromatization involves the following processes, including propane dehydrogenation to propylene, and further formation of aromatics via polymerization, cyclization, dehydrogenation, etc., which is in agreement with the experimental reaction processes [4,52,53]. Benzene is considered to be the final product of propane dehydroaromatization as it is the main product among the aromatic products [54]. Initially, propane is adsorbed near the [GaH]2+ species to form propylene via dehydrogenation. The main C6 intermediate via propylene polymerization is 4-methyl-1-pentene over the HZSM-5 catalyst in our previous work [55]. Therefore, further aromatization reactions based on 4-methyl-1-pentene are considered. There are two pathways to form benzene after the formation of 4-methyl-1-pentene. Firstly, 4-methyl-1-pentene forms 2-methyl-1,4-pentadiene via dehydrogenation, which is then cyclized in the form of the C6 diene to form a five-membered ring, and finally benzene is formed by cyclization, dehydrogenation, etc. Secondly, 4-methyl-1-pentene can also form a five-membered ring by cyclization in the form of C6 olefin, and finally to benzene by dehydrogenation, ring expansion, etc. The complete reaction pathway for propane dehydroaromatization to form benzene is shown in Scheme 2 , which includes both propane dehydrogenation and propylene aromatization. 3.3 Propane dehydrogenation on Ga-modified HZSM-5 3.3.1 Mechanisms of propane dehydrogenation The complete mechanisms of the propane dehydrogenation include the alkyl mechanism and the carbenium mechanism, as illustrated in Scheme 3 . In the alkyl mechanism, propane is initially adsorbed near the [GaH]2+ species. And then the H atom from the methyl group in propane is attracted to the framework O atom via C–H bond cleavage, while the alkyl group is attracted to the Ga atom to form the proton acid site and the gallium alkyl group intermediate. Subsequently, there are three pathways to form propylene. In A-Path-1 and A-Path-2, the H proton from the framework O and the H atom of the [GaH]2+ species combine to form H2 and is removed. For A-Path-1, the β-H of the gallium alkyl group is transferred to the framework O atom, which results in the formation and removal of propylene as well as the generation of the Ga+ species and proton acid site. Finally, the [GaH]2+ species is recovered via H transfer reaction on the Ga+ species [26]. For A-Path-2, the β-H of the gallium alkyl group is transferred to the Ga atom, which results in the direct regeneration of the [GaH]2+ species as well as the formation of propylene. In A-Path-3, unlike A-Path-2, the β-H on the gallium alkyl group combines directly with the H atom on the framework O to form propylene and H2, while the [GaH]2+ species is recovered [15]. In the carbenium mechanism, propane also initially is adsorbed near the [GaH]2+ species. And then the H atom from the methyl group in propane is attracted to the Ga atom via C–H bond cleavage, while the alkyl group is attracted to the framework O atom. Subsequently, there are two pathways to form propylene. In C-Path-1, the β-H on the gallium alkyl group is transferred to the framework O atom to form a proton acid site, which results in the formation and removal of propylene. Finally, the H atom (on the framework O) combines with the H atom (connected to the Ga atom) to form H2, while the [GaH]2+ species is restored. In C-Path-2, the β-H on the gallium alkyl group combines directly with the H atom (connected to the Ga atom) to form propylene and H2, while the [GaH]2+ species is recovered. In the carbenium mechanism, following propane adsorption near the [GaH]2+ species, the H atom from the methyl group of propane is attracted to the Ga atom via C–H bond cleavage, while the alkyl group is attracted to the framework O atom. Since the C–H bond cleavage is primarily influenced by the Ga atom, the ease of C–H bond cleavage is independent of the framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species. However, in the alkyl mechanism, the H atom from the methyl group of propane can be attracted to different framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species via C–H bond cleavage, which will influence the C–H bond activation. Considering that the C–H bond activation step in the alkyl mechanism is similar to H transfer and H2 disproportionation reactions, they all involve the transfer of H atom to different framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species. Therefore, the results of Section 3.1 are adopted for the above problem, i.e., the H atom via C–H bond cleavage in the alkyl mechanism is preferentially transferred to the framework O atom with stronger Lewis base strength and more negative Mulliken charges. To confirm this reasoning, the E a of the C–H bond activation for propane is calculated on different framework O atoms surrounding [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 site, as presented in Fig. S1. The corresponding TS structures optimized are displayed in Fig. S2. It is discovered that the E a of the C–H bond activation for propane is significantly lower on framework O-5 atom with stronger Lewis base strength and more negative Mulliken charges surrounding [GaH]2+ species than that on the other framework O atoms. The results of Section 3.1 are adopted for all C–H bond activation on [GaH]2+ species in the subsequent sections. The E a of propane dehydrogenation on Ga-modified HZSM-5 with [GaH]2+ species at T3-T11 site under different reaction pathways in Scheme 3 is calculated. The corresponding structures optimized and the specific free energy values are given in Fig. S3 and Table S5. It is found that the alkyl mechanism has a significantly lower energetic span compared to the carbenium mechanism based on the energetic span analysis, as depicted in Fig. 7 . In the alkyl mechanism, the energetic spans of A-Path-1, A-Path-2, and A-Path-3 are 349.3, 249.2, and 244.5 kJ/mol, respectively. And the total reaction energies of A-Path-1, A-Path-2, and A-Path-3 are 235.5, 86.5, and 27.9 kJ/mol, respectively. A small difference in energetic span between A-Path-2 and A-Path-3 (4.7 kJ/mol) is found, but the total reaction energy of A-Path-3 is significantly lower than A-Path-2. Consequently, the rate-determining step in all elementary steps of A-Path-2 and A-Path-3 is further analyzed. The rate-determining step in A-Path-3 is A-TS1 with an E a of 173.3 kJ/mol, which was significantly lower than A-TS3-2 in A-Path-2 with an E a of 248.0 kJ/mol. In conclusion, it is considered that the A-Path-3 in the alkyl mechanism is the optimal reaction pathway for propane dehydrogenation on Ga-modified HZSM-5 with [GaH]2+ species, which is in agreement with the mechanism concluded experimentally by measuring the rate of propane dehydrogenation [16]. In A-Path-3 of the alkyl mechanism, the first step is the C–H bond activation and the second step is the formation of the propylene and H2. The dehydrogenation reaction pathways in the propane dehydroaromatization process all adopt A-Path-3 of the alkyl mechanism in the subsequent sections. 3.3.2 Effect of the [GaH]2+ sites on the propane dehydrogenation reaction activity In this section, the activity of propane dehydrogenation reactions on Ga-modified HZSM-5 with [GaH]2+ species at different sites is investigated, as shown in Fig. 8 . The corresponding structures optimized are depicted in Fig. S4. Propane is first adsorbed near the [GaH]2+ species and then forms propylene via A-Path-3 of the alkyl mechanism. It is found that Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts with [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11, T3-T5, T8-T5, and T8-T1 sites exhibit lower energetic spans of 244.5, 247.9, 260.3, and 249.4 kJ/mol, respectively. Considering that the energetic span differences of [GaH]2+ species at these sites are small, the rate-determining step in all elementary steps of the propane dehydrogenation reaction are further analyzed. A-TS1 is the rate-determining step in the propane dehydrogenation reaction due to higher activation energy than that on A-TS2-2. The activation energies required of A-TS1 are 173.3, 150.1, 196.9, and 207.6 kJ/mol when the [GaH]2+ species are at the T3-T11 T3-T5, T8-T5, and T8-T1 sites, respectively, as seen in Fig. 8. Therefore, it suggests that the Ga-modified HZSM-5 exhibits the optimal propane dehydrogenation performance with [GaH]2+ species at T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites. It is noteworthy that the activation energy required for the rate-determining step on Ga-modified HZSM-5 with [GaH]2+ species at T3-T5 site is 150.1 kJ/mol, which is close to the intrinsic activation energy of 144.8 kJ/mol obtained experimentally by Bell and co-workers [16]. Consequently, only [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites are considered in the subsequent propylene aromatization reaction. For the [GaH]2+ species at different sites exhibiting different propane dehydrogenation activities, the structures of Ga-modified HZSM-5 with [GaH]2+ species at different sites are analyzed for microscopic properties from the HOMO-LUMO front orbital properties and the Mulliken charge of the framework O atom with the optimal dehydrogenation reaction activity surrounding [GaH]2+ species. As shown in Fig. 9 (a), the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts with [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites have lower gap values of 781.1 and 782.4 kJ/mol, respectively, which are significantly lower than that at the other sites. The lower gap values mean that electrons are more easily transferred in the propane dehydrogenation reaction, and transition state structures are more easily formed, resulting in the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts exhibiting excellent propane dehydrogenation activity [56–58]. As shown in Fig. 9(b), the framework O atoms with the optimal dehydrogenation reaction activity surrounding [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites have more negative Mulliken charges than that at the other sites, which also results in the excellent propane dehydrogenation activity of the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts. 3.4 Propylene aromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5 3.4.1 Active centers for polymerization and cyclization reactions in the propylene aromatization process In the propylene aromatization process, the dehydrogenation reaction occurs on the [GaH]2+ species (Lewis acid), while the polymerization and cyclization reactions may occur on the [GaH]2+ species or the Brønsted acid. The propylene polymerization reaction includes propylene protonation (TS5), propylene dimerization (TS6), and deprotonation of the carbenium ion intermediate (TS7), as seen in Scheme 2. It is observed that the E a is strongly dependent on the active center of the reaction, a result that the reaction activity of Brønsted acid is obviously superior to that of the [GaH]2+ species, as illustrated in Fig. 10 . The corresponding TS structures optimized can be found in Fig. S5. For the cyclization reaction of C6 diene (TS10-TS11) and C6 olefin (TS13-TS14), the E a of the rate-determining step on the [GaH]2+ species are significantly greater than that on the Brønsted acid (233.6 vs 109.6 and 298.7 vs 97.5 kJ/mol, respectively). As a result, the active center for the polymerization and cyclization reactions is the Brønsted acid during the propane aromatization process on the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts. 3.4.2 Complete reaction pathway of propylene aromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5 There are two pathways to form benzene after the formation of 4-methyl-1-pentene in Scheme 2, including the pathways of the C6 diene intermediate and the C6 olefin intermediate. The E a of the TS8-TS12 (C6 diene cyclization pathway) are 187.2, 128.7, 84.7, 109.6, and 52.1 kJ/mol, respectively. And the E a of the TS13-TS17 (C6 olefin cyclization pathway) are 79.7, 97.5, 196.4, 148.1, and 68.6 kJ/mol, respectively. The corresponding TS structures optimized are provided in Fig. S6. Therefore, the C6 diene cyclization pathway (the E a of the rate-determining step is 187.2 kJ/mol) is more favorable for the formation of benzene compared to the C6 olefin cyclization pathway (the E a of the rate-determining step is 196.4 kJ/mol). The formation of benzene among the aromatic products follows the mechanism of C6 diene intermediate, which is precursor of cyclization reaction, which is consistent with previously reported studies [59–62]. The complete reaction pathway of propylene aromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts with [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites is investigated in Fig. 11 . The corresponding structures optimized are presented in Figs. S7-S8. The specific energy values in Fig. 11 and the energy corrected at 773–973 K can be found in Tables S6-S7 . In the initial step, the propylene molecule is adsorbed near the Brønsted acid, followed by the formation of intermediate (IM5) by the protonation reaction (TS5). Subsequently, the two propylene molecules form carbenium ion intermediate (IM6) via polymerization reaction (TS6), which overcomes the E a of 95.7 (T3-T11 site) and 89.9 kJ/mol (T3-T5 site), respectively. Then, IM6 forms 4-methyl-1-pentene by deprotonation reaction (TS7), and the propylene polymerization process is completed. Afterward, 2-methyl-1,4-pentadiene is formed via the 4-methyl-1-pentene dehydrogenation reaction (TS8-TS9), overcoming the E a of 187.2, 128.7 kJ/mol (T3-T11 site) and 176.1, 130.3 kJ/mol (T3-T5 site), respectively. Subsequently, the H2 molecule is removed. After the formation of the carbenium ion intermediate (IM10) via TS10, the intermediate (IM11) is formed via cyclization reaction (TS11), overcoming the E a of 109.6 kJ/mol (T3-T11 site) and 78.6 kJ/mol (T3-T5 site). Then, IM11 forms cyclohexene through H transfer (TS12), ring expansion (TS18), and deprotonation (TS19) reactions. Finally, cyclohexene forms the final benzene via two successive dehydrogenation reactions. In the formation of cyclohexene to cyclohexadiene (TS20 and TS21), the E a is 186.4, 138.0 kJ/mol (T3-T11 site) and 184.2, 119.4 kJ/mol (T3-T5 site), respectively. Afterwards, the H2 molecule is removed. In the formation of cyclohexadiene to benzene (TS22 and TS23), the E a is 159.8, 123.9 kJ/mol (T3-T11 site) and 160.8, 90.5 kJ/mol (T3-T5 site), respectively. In the propylene aromatization reaction on Ga-modified HZSM-5, the energetic span is 322.0 kJ/mol and the total reaction energy is -235.0 kJ/mol with [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 site. And the energetic span is 282.5 kJ/mol and the total reaction energy is −184.4 kJ/mol with the [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T5 site. The three dehydrogenation reactions are the most difficult to occur, including 4-methyl-1-pentene to 2-methyl-1,4-pentadiene, cyclohexene to cyclohexadiene, and cyclohexadiene to benzene. It is discovered that propylene aromatization is more difficult to occur than propane dehydrogenation. The formation of propylene from propane is not a rate-determining step in the propane dehydroaromatization process, which is consistent with the results of Chen and co-workers [63]. 3.5 Role of Brønsted/Lewis acids synergistic effect in overall propane dehydroaromatization Based on the above discussions, the complete propane dehydroaromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5 is as follows: propane first forms propylene via dehydrogenation reaction on the [GaH]2+ species, and then the two propylene molecules form C6 olefin via polymerization reaction on the Brønsted acid. Subsequently, the C6 diene is formed on the [GaH]2+ species by dehydrogenation reaction and further form a five-membered ring via cyclization reaction on the Brønsted acid. Finally, the six-membered ring formed by ring expansion of the five-membered ring forms the final benzene on the [GaH]2+ species via two dehydrogenation reactions. The propane dehydroaromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5 is co-catalyzed by the active centers of Lewis acid ([GaH]2+ species) and Brønsted acid, but the reactions occurring on the two active centers are independent of each other. The [GaH]2+ species is not directly involved in the polymerization and cyclization reactions dominated by the Brønsted acid. Likewise, the Brønsted acid is not directly involved in the dehydrogenation reaction dominated by the [GaH]2+ species. Two cases in Scheme 4 are considered to explore whether there is an indirect synergistic effect between the [GaH]2+ species and Brønsted acid in the propane dehydroaromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5. The effect of the presence of [GaH]2+ species on the Brønsted acid is investigated by comparison of the activity of polymerization and cyclization reactions dominated by the Brønsted acid with and without the [GaH]2+ species, as shown in Scheme 4(a). The effect of the presence of Brønsted acid on the [GaH]2+ species is investigated by comparison of the activity of dehydrogenation reaction dominated by the [GaH]2+ species with and without the Brønsted acid, as shown in Scheme 4(b). 3.5.1 Effect of the presence of [GaH]2+ species on Brønsted acid During the propylene polymerization reaction, including propylene protonation (TS5), propylene dimerization (TS6), and deprotonation of the carbenium ion intermediate (TS7), the E a on HZSM-5 with pure Brønsted acid are 42.3, 103.4, and 10.0 kJ/mol, respectively, as shown in Fig. 12 . And the E a value of TS5 is consistent with the 43.7 kJ/mol reported in the literature on the 64 T cluster structure of HZSM-5 [64]. In the presence of [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites, the E a of the TS5 exhibits a slight increase, while the E a of the TS6 (the rate-determining step of propylene polymerization reaction) and TS7 has been decreased. During the C6 diene cyclization reaction, including C6 diene protonation (TS10) and cyclization of the carbenium ion intermediate (TS11), the E a on HZSM-5 with pure Brønsted acid are 84.1 and 111.6 kJ/mol, respectively. It is discovered that the presence of the [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites has little effect on TS10, whereas it can decrease the E a of TS11. It is apparent that the presence of the [GaH]2+ species improves the activity of the polymerization and cyclization reactions on the Brønsted acid. The improved activity of the polymerization and cyclization reactions is further explored by analyzing the the Brønsted acid strength. It can be seen that the Brønsted acid strength is enhanced in the presence of [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites on Ga-modified HZSM-5 compared to the HZSM-5 with pure Brønsted acid, as shown in Fig. 12. Moreover, the polymerization and cyclization reactions are more easily to occur on Brønsted acids with stronger acid strength. Therefore, in propane dehydroaromatization, the [GaH]2+ species can indirectly improve the activity of the propylene polymerization and C6 diene cyclization reactions on the Brønsted acid by enhancing the Brønsted acid strength, although not participating in the reaction pathways of the polymerization and cyclization reactions. 3.5.2 Effect of the presence of Brønsted acid on [GaH]2+ species The dehydrogenation reactions in propane dehydroaromatization include propane to propylene (A-TS1 and A-TS2-2), 4-methyl-1-pentene to 2-methyl-1,4-pentadiene (TS8 and TS9), cyclohexene to cyclohexadiene (TS20 and TS21), and cyclohexadiene to benzene (TS22 and TS23). The activity of the dehydrogenation reactions on [GaH]2+/ZSM-5 (without Brønsted acid and with [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites) and [GaH]2+/HZSM-5 (with Brønsted acid and [GaH]2+ species at T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites) is investigated. It is discovered that the presence of Brønsted acid exerts a certain inhibitory effect on the C–H bond activation (TS1, TS8, TS20, and TS22) but facilitates the formation of the olefins and H2 (TS2, TS9, TS21, and TS23) in the dehydrogenation reaction, as shown in Fig. 13 . Since the dehydrogenation reaction activity is dominated by the C–H bond activation step, the presence of the Brønsted acid does not synergistically improve the dehydrogenation activity on the [GaH]2+ species in propane dehydroaromatization. It is considered that the reactions [GaH]2++H2 → H++[GaH2]+, H++[GaH2]+→[GaH]2++H2 and the two steps of dehydrogenation reaction (the C–H bond activation and formation of the olefins and H2, respectively) on the Ga-modified HZSM-5 have a similar process. It can be assumed that the first step is the H-H bond activation ([GaH]2++H2 → H++[GaH2]+) after H2 is adsorbed near the [GaH]2+ species, and the second step is the formation of H2 (H++[GaH2]+→[GaH]2++H2) with the restoration of the [GaH]2+ species. Since the C–H bond activation is more difficult to occur compared to the formation of olefin and H2 in the dehydrogenation reaction, the H-H bond activation step ([GaH]2++H2 → H++[GaH2]+) should also be more difficult to occur compared to the formation of H2 (H++[GaH2]+→[GaH]2++H2), which is confirmed by the calculations in Section 3.1. As mentioned above, the presence of Brønsted acid exerts a certain inhibitory effect on the C–H bond activation but facilitates the formation of the olefins and H2 in the dehydrogenation reaction. Similarly, the presence of Brønsted acid will inhibit the H-H bond activation step ([GaH]2++H2 → H++[GaH2]+) and promote the formation of H2 (H++[GaH2]+→[GaH]2++H2) compared to the absence of the Brønsted acid, thereby enabling [GaH]2+ species to exist more stably kinetically. The above inference is confirmed by the calculations of the rate constant of [GaH]2++H2 ↔ H++[GaH2]+ on Ga-modified HZSM-5 with and without Brønsted acid. It is found that the presence of Brønsted acid has little effect on the rate constant of [GaH]2++H2 → H++[GaH2]+, but significantly increases the rate constant of H++[GaH2]+→[GaH]2++H2, as shown in Fig. 14 , and the specific values are given in Table S8. The difference between the forward and reverse reactions rate constant becomes larger with Brønsted acid compared to that without Brønsted acid. The Brønsted acid leads to the conversion of the [GaH2]+ species to the [GaH]2+ species more easily, thereby enabling the [GaH]2+ species to exist more stably kinetically on Ga-modified HZSM-5. In addition, the reaction energies in Table S9 indicate that [GaH]2+ species at T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites exhibit thermodynamic stability with and without Brønsted acid. In summary, the synergistic effect between [GaH]2+ species and Brønsted acid is reflected in the fact that the [GaH]2+ species can indirectly improve the activity of propylene polymerization and C6 diene cyclization reactions on the Brønsted acid by enhancing the Brønsted acid strength, and in turn, the Brønsted acid enables the [GaH]2+ species to exist more stably kinetically by promoting the conversion of [GaH2]+ species to [GaH]2+ species. 4 Conclusions The complete reaction process of propane dehydroaromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5 is investigated based on the DFT method, including propane dehydrogenation to propylene, and further formation of aromatics via polymerization, cyclization, dehydrogenation, etc. Firstly, the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts with [GaH]2+ species at all studied sites exhibit superior thermodynamic and kinetic stability by analyzing the conversion of [GaH]2+ species to [GaH2]+ and Ga+ species. Secondly, In propane dehydroaromatization, the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts with [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites exhibit excellent dehydrogenation performance due to more negative Mulliken charges of the framework O atom surrounding [GaH]2+ species and lower gap values between HOMO and LUMO of the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts. It is revealed that the dehydrogenation reactions dominated by [GaH]2+ species tend to occur on the framework O atom surrounding [GaH]2+ species with stronger Lewis base strength, while polymerization and cyclization reactions dominated by Brønsted acid tend to occur on Brønsted acid with stronger acid strength. The formation of benzene in aromatic products follows the mechanism of diene intermediate, which is precursor of the cyclization reaction. Thirdly, the [GaH]2+ species can indirectly improve the reaction activity of propylene polymerization and C6 diene cyclization reactions on the Brønsted acid by enhancing the Brønsted acid strength, although not participating in the pathways of polymerization and cyclization reactions. In turn, the Brønsted acid enables the [GaH]2+ species to exist more stably kinetically by promoting the conversion of [GaH2]+ species to [GaH]2+ species. This study provides new insights into the Brønsted/Lewis acid synergistic effect and the role of acidity-basicity during propane dehydroaromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5. coredata.dc:description: The HZSM-5 catalyst modified with Ga species exhibits excellent reaction performance for propane dehydroaromatization, a process that involves propane dehydrogenation to propylene, and further formation of aromatics via polymerization, cyclization, dehydrogenation, etc. The detailed mechanism of the synergistic effect between Ga species and Brønsted acid with each other during propane dehydroaromatization remains unclear due to the complexity and extreme branching of aromatization reaction pathways. In this study, the complete reaction process for propane dehydroaromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5 is investigated based on the density functional theory (DFT) method. The results indicate that the Ga-modified HZSM-5 catalysts with [GaH]2+ species at all studied sites show superior thermodynamic and kinetic stability, with only [GaH]2+ species at the T3-T11 and T3-T5 sites exhibiting excellent dehydrogenation performance. In propane dehydroaromatization, the dehydrogenation reactions dominated by [GaH]2+ species tend to occur on the framework O atom surrounding [GaH]2+ species with stronger Lewis base strength, while polymerization and cyclization reactions dominated by Brønsted acid tend to occur on Brønsted acid with stronger acid strength. The synergistic effect between [GaH]2+ species and Brønsted acid is reflected in the fact that the [GaH]2+ species can indirectly improve the activity of propylene polymerization and C6 diene cyclization reactions on the Brønsted acid by enhancing the Brønsted acid strength, and in turn, the Brønsted acid enables the [GaH]2+ species to exist more stably kinetically by promoting the conversion of [GaH2]+ species to [GaH]2+ species. This study contributes to the enriched understanding of the Brønsted/Lewis acid synergistic effect and the role of acidity-basicity during propane dehydroaromatization on Ga-modified HZSM-5.
